docs.lead_paragraph: Box-office giants mixed with independent-film newcomers at the 57th annual Golden Globe Awards tonight at the drizzle-drenched Beverly Hilton Hotel, with established stars like Jim Carrey, Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington joining relative movie newcomers like Hilary Swank, Janet McTeer and Angelina Jolie among the winners. ''American Beauty,'' a scabrous comedy about dysfunctional suburbanites that is considered a front-runner for the Academy Awards, won for best drama. Sam Mendes, the British stage director who brought the Tony-winning ''Cabaret'' to Broadway, won best director for the film, his first motion picture. ''American Beauty'' also won best screenplay honors for Alan Ball.
docs.abstract: American Beauty wins for best drama at 57th annual Golden Globe Awards; movie's director, Sam Mendes, and its screenwriter, Alan Ball, also win awards; computer-animated Toy Story 2 wins for best comedy or musical; Jim Carrey wins for best actor in comedy, Man on the Moon, and Denzel Washington is named best actor in drama, The Hurricane; Hilary Swank wins best actress in drama, Boys Don't Cry, and Janet McTeer wins best actress in comedy, Tumbleweeds; in television awards, HBO is big winner; The Sopranos wins for best dramatic series, and awards go to its two lead stars, James Gandolfini and Edie Falco, and to Nancy Marchand in supporting role; HBO's Sex and the City wins for best comedy series and for best actress, Sarah Jessica Parker; HBO's RKO 281 wins as best television movie or mini-series; Barbra Streisand receives Cecil B De Mille Award for lifetime achievement; photo (M)

docs.snippet: I AM poised on a narrow ledge that angles downward to the street below. Drops of water fall from the mop in my left hand and form a momentary trail before scattering in the breeze. My right hand grips a cold metal frame while a squeegee dangles fr...
docs.lead_paragraph: I AM poised on a narrow ledge that angles downward to the street below. Drops of water fall from the mop in my left hand and form a momentary trail before scattering in the breeze. My right hand grips a cold metal frame while a squeegee dangles from my waist. I am 55 stories up and set to clean a window. At that height, wind is a factor, so I hug the building close. I look down to get my bearings; looking up can induce vertigo. Because I am on a postwar high-rise, there are no hooks to which I can secure my window cleaner's belt. I can only rely on my fingertips and sense of balance. Still, I take advantage of my perch for a moment to admire the Chrysler Building a few blocks north. I feel a part of the skyline.
docs.abstract: Article by Ivor Hanson, who is writing book about his experiences as window washer, describes what it is like to wash windows on Manhattan buildings; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CATSIFF-Oscar. On January 18, at age 96, in New Port Richey, FL. Beloved husband of the late Molly Catsiff, loving father of Ruth and Dr. Frank Harold and Beth and Dr. Allen Unger, adoring grandfather of Stephanie Harold and Ben McLuckie, Allison Unger and Eric Prager, David Unger and Bradley Unger and great grandfather of Jordan McLuckie. He graduated Harvard University cum laude in 1926. He worked for the Irving Berlin Music Company as a music arranger and then as a music editor and arranger for Chappell & Co. until his retirement in 1968. He continued to write music and give public piano performances until shortly before his death.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nothing is more stubbornly French than the devotion to perfect seams. One can go to any haute couture house and find the same people bent over the same tables, pulling the same needles, absorbed in the same conversations that, in another era, would not have been remarkably different. Even Karl Lagerfeld, who is German and runs the most informal couture studio in Paris, was not beyond closing ranks when he said of his pretty Chanel spring collection, ''It's not a trip to Africa or India; it's a Paris trip.'' Yet, in ways that nobody has bothered to notice, the real spirit of haute couture today lies closer to the American West Coast than uptight old Paris. The women who buy couture, who pay upward of $50,000 for an evening dress, arrive in the front row in such a profusion of hair and modern dentistry that it would be hilarious if they weren't so friendly and their wealth didn't come from such improbable new sources, like supplying those TV helicopters you see whizzing over Los Angeles to cover traffic and police chases.

The practice, Mr. Angeloni writes, ''counts among its practitioners some of the most dapper, if idiosyncratic gentlemen of the century.'' Any affectation that unites Oscar Wilde and James Bond is worth looking into. A further clipping: The book includes a guide to state flowers. Should Tony Soprano really wear purple violets?

docs.lead_paragraph: Vernon Forrest will step into a ring in Las Vegas tonight for the 31st time as a professional boxer. It will not be a title fight. Although he is undefeated in eight years as a pro and is considered one of the best welterweights in the world, Forrest has never been given a chance to fight a champion. Stephan Johnson, a Brooklyn-born boxer, never got a title fight, either. He died of injuries suffered during a bout in Atlantic City two months ago. Canadian authorities had suspended him for medical reasons last April, but officials in New Jersey, South Carolina and Georgia continued to let him fight, despite a CAT scan suggesting that he might have a brain injury and should have more medical tests.
docs.abstract: Special report, A Sport Adrift, discusses professional boxing's lack of central governing body to enforce safety rules, create credible rankings and insure that best fighters advance; federal court has now, for first time, stepped in, appointing monitor to run International Boxing Federation, only American-based group that ranks professional fighters; action follows November indictment of four organization officials on charges of soliciting bribes from managers and promoters; Lou DiBella of HBO and New York Atty Gen Elliot Spitzer explain complex corruption; regulations and enforcement vary from state to state, contracts are often written to exploit young fighters, and sanctioning organizations do not rank each other's champions, so that there is proliferation of titles but few fights between best fighters; promoters are businessmen who sign up fighters, stage bouts and sell broadcast rights; examples of problems are Vernon Forrest, who is unbeaten in 30 fights but has not been given chance at title challenge, and Stephen Johnson, who died of brain injuries amid questions of why he was approved to fight; photos (L)
